Issue 484
  • GHC 9.10.3-rc2: Second release candidate is now available.
  • Weeder 2.10: Released with support for GHC 9.10 and 9.12, featuring significant performance improvements.
  • HLS Plugin: A draft PR is available for a new "Go To Underlying Type" plugin for the Haskell Language Server.
  • Libraries:
    • heterogeneous-comparison: A new library for comparing values of different types while capturing evidence of type equality.
    • twentyseven: A Rubik's cube solver library, has reached version 1.0.0.
    • Dataframe: A call for new contributors has been posted.
  • Articles & Tutorials:
    • An article argues against the necessity of monads, referencing the Я language which does not use them.
    • A tutorial series demonstrates building a bytecode VM and parser for arithmetic.
    • A RealWorld example application built with the effectful library has been open-sourced.
  • Tooling & Development:
    • A developer shared their Nix configuration for a monorepo containing both Haskell and the Lean proof assistant.
    • A discussion is underway to add a shorter command-line alias for the --stack-yaml flag in the Stack build tool.
Wikipedia loses challenge against Online Safety Act verification rules
wikipediaonline safety actuklawlegalregulationprivacyidentity verification
  • Legal Action: The Wikimedia Foundation lost a judicial review challenging the UK's Online Safety Act regulations.
  • Core Conflict: Wikimedia argued that the act's "Category 1" classification, intended for large social media sites, was too broad and improperly applied to Wikipedia.
  • Primary Concern: If classified as "Category 1," Wikipedia might be forced to implement identity verification for its contributors, which it claims would undermine the privacy and safety of its volunteer editors.
  • Court's Ruling: The High Court dismissed the challenge to the lawfulness of the government's decision-making process for the regulations.
  • Future Implications: The judgment leaves open the possibility for future legal challenges, specifically against Ofcom's potential decision to classify Wikipedia as "Category 1" or if the act's implementation makes the site's operation unviable.
